statement.text: The reduced Planck constant (ℏ, 'h-bar') is the fundamental quantum of action in physics, equal to Planck's constant divided by 2π. It appears in the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, the Schrödinger equation, and is the foundation for all Planck units. Since the 2019 SI redefinition, h is exactly 6.62607015 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s, making ℏ an exact constant with no uncertainty.

explanation.intuition: The reduced Planck constant ℏ is the 'atom' of action - the smallest possible change in action that nature allows. It sets the scale for all quantum phenomena: the uncertainty principle (ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2), quantized angular momentum (L = nℏ), and energy levels (E = ℏω). Every Planck unit - length, time, mass, energy, temperature - contains ℏ in its formula. It's the 'ℏ' in 'quantum mechanics'.
explanation.key_insight: The most remarkable fact about ℏ is that since May 20, 2019, it is EXACT with zero uncertainty! The SI system was redefined to fix h = 6.62607015 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s exactly, making ℏ = h/(2π) = 1.054571817... × 10⁻³⁴ J·s also exact. This means ℏ is now a defined constant, not a measured one. It appears in ALL Planck units: ℓₚ = √(ℏG/c³), tₚ = √(ℏG/c⁵), mₚ = √(ℏc/G), Eₚ = √(ℏc⁵/G), Tₚ = √(ℏc⁵/Gk²), qₚ = √(4πε₀ℏc), pₚ = √(ℏc³/G). Without ℏ, there would be no Planck units!
explanation.technical_details: The reduced Planck constant ℏ = h/(2π) was introduced because 2π appears repeatedly in quantum mechanics formulas. For example, angular momentum L = nℏ (not nh), de Broglie wavelength λ = h/p = 2π(ℏ/p), Schrödinger equation iℏ∂ψ/∂t = Ĥψ, commutation [x̂,p̂] = iℏ, uncertainty ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2. The 2019 SI redefinition fixed h exactly, which also fixed ℏ. Previously, h had uncertainty ±0.000000081 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s (CODATA 2014). Now: h = 6.62607015 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s (exact), so ℏ = 1.054571817... × 10⁻³⁴ J·s (exact, infinite decimal). Dimension: [ℏ] = energy × time = action.
common_misconceptions: ℏ is NOT still measured with uncertainty - it's been EXACT since 2019!
ℏ is NOT the same as h - it's h/(2π) ≈ h/6.28
Uncertainty principle is NOT 'ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ' but 'ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2' (factor of 2!)
ℏ is NOT just for quantum mechanics - it appears in statistical mechanics, thermodynamics, and defines Planck units
Setting ℏ = 1 in natural units is NOT 'ignoring it' - it's choosing units where quantum effects are normalized

definitions_glossary.reduced_planck_constant: ℏ = h/(2π) = 1.054571817... × 10⁻³⁴ J·s, fundamental quantum of action (exact since 2019)
definitions_glossary.planck_constant: h = 6.62607015 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s, original quantum constant from Planck's black body radiation (exact since 2019)
definitions_glossary.action: Physical quantity with dimensions [energy × time], measured in J·s; ℏ is the quantum unit
definitions_glossary.quantum_of_angular_momentum: Elementary unit L₀ = ℏ; all angular momenta are integer multiples: L = nℏ
definitions_glossary.heisenberg_uncertainty: ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2, fundamental limit on simultaneous knowledge of position and momentum
definitions_glossary.schrödinger_equation: iℏ∂ψ/∂t = Ĥψ, fundamental equation of quantum mechanics containing ℏ
definitions_glossary.commutation_relation: [x̂,p̂] = iℏ, canonical commutator defining quantum mechanics algebra
definitions_glossary.natural_units: Unit system where ℏ = c = k = 1, simplifying quantum and relativistic formulas
definitions_glossary.si_redefinition_2019: Redefinition of SI units fixing h exactly, making kilogram derived from h, ℏ, and c
definitions_glossary.de_broglie_wavelength: λ = h/p = 2πℏ/p, quantum wavelength associated with momentum p

validation.notes: Exact value verified from 2019 SI redefinition. Historical development and all quantum mechanics applications validated. Centrality to all Planck units confirmed.

learning_objectives: Define reduced Planck constant and distinguish from Planck's constant h
Understand ℏ as the quantum of action and its exact value since 2019
Recognize ℏ in all fundamental quantum equations (uncertainty, Schrödinger, commutation)
Explain why ℏ appears in ALL Planck units
Apply ℏ in quantum mechanics calculations and natural units
common_errors: Thinking ℏ still has measurement uncertainty (exact since 2019!)
Confusing ℏ with h (they differ by factor of 2π)
Writing ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ instead of ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2 (missing factor 1/2)
Forgetting that Planck force is the ONLY Planck unit without ℏ
Not recognizing ℏ as foundation of entire Planck unit system
physics_insights: ℏ = h/(2π) eliminates 2π factors throughout quantum mechanics - more 'natural' than h
Since 2019, ℏ is exact: SI kilogram is now DEFINED from ℏ, c, and cesium frequency
Every Planck unit except Fₚ contains ℏ - it's the quantum foundation
Uncertainty ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2 with minimum ℏ/2 for Gaussian wavepackets
Commutator [x̂,p̂] = iℏ is the algebraic heart of quantum mechanics
Angular momentum quantization L = nℏ: orbital (n integer), spin (n half-integer)
Natural units ℏ = 1 reveal that quantum effects are normalized at Planck scale
ℏ connects frequency to energy (E = ℏω) and wavelength to momentum (p = ℏk)
